text: first false positive (or negative? :thinking_face:) detected: <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/31646#issuecomment-795635957> (I'm talking about missing license)
well, to be honest it isn't clear to me what's the license of the package :thinking_face:

text: the solution apparently was to dump the GPL license: <https://github.com/StatisticalRethinkingJulia/StatisticalRethinking.jl/commit/8ebd93fc95362b98aa94b0512a3646b4c5548a8c>

elements.text: the solution apparently was to dump the GPL license:

text: which is great because it's super long, so the 70% threshold is easy to match even if there is some other text :joy:  CC: <@UCZ7VBGUD>

elements.text: which is great because it's super long, so the 70% threshold is easy to match even if there is some other text

text: Yeah.. the license is kind of strange eh? it’s not saying this code is under that license, it’s saying some other code is under that license

elements.text: Yeah.. the license is kind of strange eh? it’s not saying this code is under that license, it’s saying some other code is under that license

text: I think it’s pretty hard to use thresholds to distinguish between “License.md: the code in this repo is not licensed, but here is a copy of an unrelated license: …“, and “License.md: This code is copyright 2020 and available under the following license: …“. Seems like you need some kind of semantic / NLP thing to get further… and don’t think we want to get into that in RegistryCI at this stage

elements.text: I think it’s pretty hard to use thresholds to distinguish between “License.md: the code in this repo is not licensed, but here is a copy of an unrelated license: …“, and “License.md: This code is copyright 2020 and available under the following license: …“. Seems like you need some kind of semantic / NLP thing to get further… and don’t think we want to get into that in RegistryCI at this stage
